awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Reading lithology from topography: How rock properties influence landscape form and evolution in the Guadalupe Mountains, TX and NM
awd_abstract_narration:
The shape of landscapes partly depends on the physical properties of the bedrock that underlies them (e.g., how strong different rock types are in different places, how fractured the rocks are, and how easily particular rocks break down to make soil and sediment, also known as weathering). It should be possible to "read" rock properties from landscape form (topography), but we currently lack a quantitative relationship that can be used practically. For example, the likelihood of landslides depends on rock and soil properties. Past tectonic activity and the potential for future earthquakes along faults can also potentially be inferred from topography, but the effects of tectonics must be isolated from rock property controls on landscape form. Predicting land surface properties would also be beneficial for planning access to remote areas following natural disasters or during human conflicts. The researchers will develop teaching modules based on the Guadalupe Mountains to use in a dual enrollment (i.e., college credit for high school students) geoscience course taught through UT Austin that provides college credit to high school students across Texas.  High school geoscience and environmental science teachers will be trained through intensive and fun field workshops to be taught in the Guadalupe Mountains.

This project uses the Guadalupe Mountains in Texas and New Mexico as a natural laboratory to understand how rock properties can be inferred from topography. In addition to (a) using geographic information system analysis to relate meter-scale topographic data and digital geology maps, the researchers will also (b) make extensive field measurements of rock properties across this landscape, (c) determine long-term bedrock erosion rates by measuring cosmogenic radionuclide concentrations from rock samples, and (d) evaluate open-source computer models that predict how landscapes will evolve through time, and improve these models to better incorporate rock properties into their equations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goals of our project were to understand how bedrock strength and boulders control patterns of erosion along mountain rivers, and how bedrock properties can better be measured—“read”—from the topography of steep eroding landscapes. The topography of mountainous areas is shaped by patterns of erosion, which in turn are controlled in part by tectonics, climate, and the strength and related physical properties of the bedrock along river channels. This project focused on the control by bedrock properties, which arguably is less well understood based on previous work than climatic and tectonic controls. Rock properties control bedrock erodibility—basically, how easy it is to erode down along river channels during floods. In addition, mountain rivers transport sediment, which usually includes coarse grain sizes from gravels to boulders. Coarse sediment is created from the erosion of bedrock in the upstream watershed, and so also depends on both bedrock properties and erosion patterns. The feedbacks between the coarse sediment load (which influences channel downcutting), rock properties (which influence both sediment production and downcutting), channel slope (a key aspect of topography), channel width, and local erosion rate make unraveling these factors challenging and interesting.

We used a combination of field work, topographic analysis and numerical modeling to address these goals.  Field work and topographic analysis focused on the Guadalupe Mountains in Texas and New Mexico. This area is good for isolating bedrock properties from other controls on erosion because the area is tectonically inactive and spatial variations in climate are small compared to many other natural mountain ranges. The landscape is made up of sedimentary rock layers that are approximately horizontal and come in a variety of types and strengths (e.g., limestone, sandstone, shale, and evaporite rocks such as gypsum).

In this landscape, we found that channel steepness (basically a topographic measure of whether a channel reach had a higher or lower slope) varies systematically with previously mapped rock units based on bedrock geology maps.  We used unit descriptions of the rock types and heterogeneity within different units to independently predict bedrock erodibility based on reasonable assumptions. Our bedrock erodibility estimates could explain a majority of the variability in channel steepness, which is a result that potentially could be useful for understanding rock property controls on the topography of other large landscapes.  We also mapped the spatial distribution of boulders along extended channel reaches from field measurements, drone surveys, and other aerial imagery to independently explore the possible control of boulders on channel steepness, and how much boulders in this landscape vary with local rock type. We mapped channel width from aerial imagery (validated with field measurements) because wider channel sections may be less erosive (since flood flows are spread out over a wider area), whereas channel narrowing may enhance local erosion. Somewhat surprisingly, we found little systematic variation (in our preliminary and ongoing analysis) between local width, boulder distribution, and channel steepness in the analyzed parts of this landscape. 

To both generalize our understanding and improve interpretations of Guadalupe Mountains field data, we also conducted numerical modeling. We modified and improved an existing landscape evolution model, which accounts for some aspects of coarse sediment transport on bedrock erosion, to also include horizontal rock layers with different erodibilities. Without effects of sediment reducing erosion rates, differences in bedrock erodibility resulted in relatively large differences in channel reach steepness, with stronger layers being much steeper than weaker layers. The addition of sediment reduced overall erosion, resulting overall steeper channels (because channel slopes needed to stay relatively high to transport the coarse sediment), but also greatly reducing the topographic difference between stronger and weaker layers. Counterintuitively, we also found that the addition of course sediment resulted in stronger layers being less steep, because the weaker layers were steeper and undermined the strong layers less.  This work demonstrated that the relationship between rock properties and topography along channels is fundamentally non-unique because coarse sediment moving through the channels also influences channel steepness.  At the same time, the result explains why topographic variations along channels are usually less than would be predicted based on rock strength measurements alone. Finally, this project supported broader impacts through graduate student training and PhD research, undergraduate research, and also high school teacher geoscience education through a teacher field trip exploring Texas geology.
